Context:
Program Name: Financial Planning
Code: B407
Credential: Ontario College Graduate Certificate
Duration: 8 months (2 semesters)
Starting Months: January, May, September
Domestic Tuition: $4,115.00
International Tuition: $18,253.00
Program Location: St. James Campus
Related Programs: ["International Business Management (Postgraduate) (B411)", "Marketing Management – Financial Services (Postgraduate) (B406)", "Project Management (Postgraduate) (B415)"]
Program Description: The Financial Planning graduate certificate is an eight-month program that gives students the skills to help others reach their financial and lifestyle goals. Graduates enjoy jobs as financial advisors, personal banking officers, and investment advisors. Skills learned include assessing a client’s current and future financial position, advising on retirement, estate planning, insurance and risk management, and creating comprehensive financial plans for clients with complex needs. This program is part of the Centre for Business within the School of Accounting and Finance.
Career Opportunities: Financial services companies
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Financial Planning Program (Postgraduate) B407 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
Extracted Information:

1. Career Options after completing the financial planning program at George Brown College include: financial advisor/planner, financial services representative, personal banking officer, and investment advisor.
2. For further study options, students can refer to the transfer guide.
3. Graduates may wish to pursue credentials or certifications in the financial services sector such as Qualified Associate Financial Planner (QAFP®) and Certified Financial Planner (CFP®) through FP Canada. Canadian Securities Course (CSC) can be obtained from the Canadian Securities Institute, and Life License Qualification Program (LLQP) can be obtained from Oliver’s Learning or another approved provider followed by the provincial licensing exam.
4. The B407 program requires completion of 12 mandatory courses.
5. Required Courses for Semester 1: Math of Finance of Investment (MATH 4001), Canadian Investments I (FIN 4024), Personal Financial Planning (FIN 4004), Retirement Planning I (FIN 4005), Business & Family Law (LAW 4002), Income Tax Fundamentals (FIN 4017), Career Planning (FIN 4023).
6. Required Courses for Semester 2: Insurance in Financial Planning (FIN 4026), Canadian Investments II (FIN 4025), Income Tax Planning (FIN 4018), Estate Planning (FIN 4010).
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Financial Planning Program (Postgraduate) B407 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text provides information about a graduate program in Financial Planning offered by the college. The following are the key factual information extracted from the text:

1. Course Offerings: FIN 4018 (Income Tax Planning), FIN 4017, FIN 4010 (Estate Planning), FIN 4004, FIN 4012, and MATH 4001, FIN 4004, FIN 4005, FIN 4017.
2. Course Outlines and Learning Outcomes: The graduate will be able to integrate ethical decision-making processes into financial planning, apply recognized financial planning principles, prepare accurate financial plans, integrate economic and personal information for effective financial planning decisions, compare and contrast financial products and services, effectively market financial products, recognize tax and legal implications, communicate effectively with clients, research market opportunities and implement a business plan, and qualify to challenge industry-credentialing exams such as the Canadian Securities Course I.
3. Tuition and Fees: The estimated tuition for the first two semesters of the program starting in Fall 2023 is $4,115 for domestic students and $18,253 for international students. However, these fees do not include books, which are to be purchased separately. The fees are subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2024 and at later dates.
4. Industry-Credentialing Exams: The program teaches the curriculum required to prepare to write industry-credentialing exams such as the Canadian Securities Course I.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Financial Planning Program (Postgraduate) B407 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text provides information about exams required to become a professional in various financial fields at George Brown College, along with some important notes for international students and financial assistance. Here is the extracted information:

1. Exams Required:
   - Canadian Securities Course I and II (CSC I and CSC II)
   - Qualified Associate Financial Planner (QAFP®) Exam
   - Certified Financial Planner® (CFP®) exam
   - Life License Qualification Program (LLQP)
   - an approved LLQP training course
   - LLQP provincial examination

2. Websites for more information:
   - FP Canada
   - Canadian Securities Institute
   - Oliver's Learning (or another approved provider)
   - Financial Services Regulatory Authority of Ontario

3. OSAP Funding:
   - This program is approved for OSAP funding, provided the applicant meets OSAP eligibility criteria.

4. Admission Requirements:
   - College advanced diploma (three-year) or bachelor's degree or demonstrated relevant work experience.

5. English Language Proficiency:
   - Applicants with international transcripts who do not provide English proficiency test results must take the George Brown College English assessment to be considered for admission.
   - Applicants based solely on their work experience will be required to provide proof of English proficiency at the college level and may be required to write the George Brown College English admission assessment.

6. Country-specific Admission Requirements:
   - International students should visit the International Admissions page for more information.

7. Application Process:
   - Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges.
   - International Students should apply through the How to Apply page.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Financial Planning Program (Postgraduate) B407 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text provides information on how to apply to George Brown College, particularly for international and domestic students. It also mentions various contacts and resources for different inquiries, such as admission requirements, financial aid, and program advising. Here is the extracted information:

- International students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.
- Information sessions are held regularly on campus. Domestic students can sign up for an upcoming session.
- For inquiries about domestic admissions, contact the Admissions Office at admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit the Admissions section.
- For international student inquiries, contact one of the international recruitment representatives by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry, and visit the International Contact Us page for more information.
- For financial aid inquiries, contact the Financial Aid Office at FinAid@georgebrown.ca or visit the Financial Aid section.
- To make an appointment with an Entry Advisor, please review the frequently asked questions.
- The Centre for Business can be contacted for general inquiries at business@georgebrown.ca or (416) 415-5000 ext. 2160. For program-specific inquiries related to the Financial Planning program, contact either Tracey Britt or Carolyn Fallis through their respective emails.
- The program is offered out of the School of Accounting and Finance and classes take place at the St. James Campus, predominantly at the location labeled "Financial Planning (B407)".
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Financial Planning Program (Postgraduate) B407 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context: The Centre for Business at George Brown College offers accounting and finance programs with classes taking place primarily at 200 King St. E. and 290 Adelaide St. E., Toronto, ON, Canada. Campus tours are offered regularly, and virtual tours are available. related programs include International Business Management (Postgraduate) (B411), Marketing Management – Financial Services (Postgraduate) (B406), and Project Management (Postgraduate) (B415). George Brown College has a welcoming environment and has prepared graduates for jobs in various industries, including banking and stock brokerage firms. For more information, visitors can book campus tours, info sessions, or sign up to receive tailored resources for their applications. Interested individuals can sign up with their first name, last name, email, domestic or international status, and country. The college encourages email communications from George Brown College which can be unsubscribed at any time.
